channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Once, This Was Iraqi Farmland. Now It’s Controlled by an Iran-Linked Militia.
item.description: Iran-backed forces are assembling drones and retrofitting rockets in the territory of an American ally. They are used in attacks on U.S. outposts in Iraq and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Emily Garthwaite
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times
item.media:description: A displaced Sunni resident walks along the border of Jurf al-Nasr in September. The area, a swath of farmland about 40 miles southwest of Baghdad, is controlled by members of an Iraqi militia linked to Iran.

item.title: Where Did All the Hong Kong Neon Go?
item.description: A government crackdown on neon signs stems from safety and environmental concerns, but the campaign evokes the fading of the city itself.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times

item.title: While Gazans Suffer, Hamas Reaps the Benefits
item.description: It has gained prestige among Palestinians while poisoning Israel’s relations with the Arab world and putting the Palestinian issue back on the Western agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings this month in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: COP28: At Dubai’s Climate Summit, Protesters Test the Limits
item.description: The annual U.N. talks have brought the rare spectacle of limited protests to the politically repressive United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Activists demanding payments to poor countries harmed by climate change gathered on Wednesday at the COP28 conference in Dubai, the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Britons Love the N.H.S. Some Will Also Pay to Avoid It.
item.description: With millions-long lines for routine surgery, it has become more common for patients to pay for procedures. That carries risks for the future of the treasured public system.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Haselgrove flew to a clinic in Lithuania to have hip replacement surgery, joining a growing number of British patients who have used their own money to pay for procedures.

item.title: In Soldiers’ Remains, Russia Plots a Way to Reconcile With France
item.description: A man with close ties to the Kremlin went looking for and found the remains of World War I Russian soldiers in France. Moscow hopes to use the discovery for diplomatic purposes.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Veterans with French military honored flags at the graves of Russian soldiers from World War I at the national cemetery of Saint-Hilaire-le-Grand in France in October.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Arab Nations Condemn U.S. for Vetoing Cease-Fire Resolution
item.description: The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, said the move was “a mark of shame” for the United States.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers near the border with Gaza on Saturday as smoke rises after Israeli strikes.

item.title: U.S. Vetoes Gaza Cease-Fire Resolution at U.N. Security Council
item.description: The veto came amid a warning that “civil order is breaking down” in Gaza, and a day after the Biden administration warned that Israel’s military had not done enough to reduce harm to civilians.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Michael Levenson, Aaron Boxerman and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians set up a makeshift camp in the Al-Muwasi area of the southern Gaza Strip on Thursday.

item.title: Iran Looks to Houthi Proxies to Escalate Fight With Israel
item.description: The Iranian-backed militia in Yemen has launched drone and missile attacks on Israeli and American targets. American officials fear the group could go too far and incite a wider war.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Houthi fighters who have volunteered to fight in Gaza against Israel during a parade this month in Sana, Yemen.

item.title: Teenagers Convicted in France in Connection With Teacher Samuel Paty’s Killing
item.description: The teacher, Samuel Paty, was beheaded in 2020 by an Islamist extremist after showing caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad to his students to illustrate free speech.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mourner laying flowers near a school in Eragny-sur-Oise in 2021 during a ceremony held one year after Samuel Paty, a teacher, was beheaded by an extremist.

item.title: Putin Says He Will Seek Another Term as Russia’s President
item.description: The announcement was long expected after the Constitution was amended in 2020, effectively allowing the Russian leader to stay in power until 2036.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showed President Vladimir V. Putin speaking in Moscow on Friday during a medal ceremony for military personnel.

item.title: Two Canadians Who Police Link to Neo-Nazis Face Terrorism Charges
item.description: The men created extremist manifestoes and recruiting videos, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Dave Chan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Royal Canadian Mounted Police headquarters in Ottawa. Canada has declared the Atomwaffen Division, a far-right group that the police linked to two defendants, a terrorist organization.

item.title: Notre-Dame’s Fire-Damaged Spire Rises Again
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron had vowed to rebuild within five years from a blaze that marred the famed Paris cathedral. So far, the schedule is on track.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: After a devastating fire in 2019, President Emmanuel Macron of France vowed Notre-Dame would be rebuilt within five years — an ambitious deadline that officials are increasingly confident will be met.

item.title: Life for the Lowest Class in Ancient Pompeii? It Was Awful.
item.description: Excavations in the ancient ruins have unearthed a cramped space where enslaved workers and donkeys performed their grueling tasks.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The site of a “bakery-prison” in the ruins of Pompeii, where slaves and donkeys were locked up to grind the grain needed to make bread.

item.title: Canada’s Biggest Fossil Fuel Proponents Make Their Case at Climate Conference
item.description: Danielle Smith, the premier of Alberta, and Scott Moe of Saskatchewan made their way to the U.N. climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Many at the climate summit want an end to fossil fuels.

item.title: Fears of a NATO Withdrawal Rise as Trump Seeks a Return to Power
item.description: Current and former European diplomats said there was growing concern a second Trump presidency could mean an American retreat from the continent and a gutting of NATO.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has made it clear that he primarily sees NATO as a drain on American resources.

item.title: The Palestinian Authority’s leader assails the U.S. veto of a U.N. cease-fire resolution.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Matt Surman
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken meeting with a delegation from the Organization of Islamic Cooperation and Arab League at the State Department on Friday to discuss Gaza.

item.title: Waltzing Matilda
item.description: A farewell, of sorts.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunset at St. Kilda Beach in Melbourne last year.

item.title: Both Israel and Hamas Tell of Failed Attempt to Rescue Hostages in Gaza
item.description: The two sides made competing claims about deaths and injuries inflicted in the mission on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Israeli army spokesman, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, in Tel Aviv last month.

item.title: Pro-Palestinian Protest in NYC Denounces U.S. Veto of Cease-Fire Resolution
item.description: The demonstration, called “Shut Down Wall Street” and meant to urge an end to the United States’ financial support of Israel, became a forum to express anger over the U.S. veto.
item.dc:creator: Julian Roberts-Grmela and Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Claudia De La Cruz leading a chant as she and other pro-Palestinian protesters demonstrate in Lower Manhattan on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Sticks to Its Position on Israel as Gaza Crisis Deepens
item.description: The Biden administration is pressing Israel to do more to protect civilians. But it has not publicly discussed any consequences if it does not.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from Israeli airstrikes on Gaza. Israel’s assault has been profoundly disproportionate to the Hamas attacks that provoked it, Arab leaders say.

item.title: E.U. Agrees on AI Act, Landmark Regulation for Artificial Intelligence
item.description: The agreement over the A.I. Act solidifies one of the world’s first comprehensive attempts to limit the use of artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Lawmakers discussed the A.I. Act in June at the European Parliament.

item.title: How ‘India’s Daughters’ Became a Times Series
item.description: What was keeping Indian women out of the workplace? Times journalists explored that question in a six-part newsletter series.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends and family preparing Arti for her wedding night in Sasaram, India.

item.title: Israel Defends Detention and Stripping of Gazan Men Amid Outrage
item.description: The detentions and images of the men, tied up and wearing only underwear, prompted an international outcry. Israel said it was seeking to determine which were with Hamas and stripped them to ensure they were unarmed.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Raja Abdulrahim and Arijeta Lajka
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Jabaliya.

item.title: New Sickle Cell Therapies Will Be Out of Reach Where They Are Needed Most
item.description: There is no clear path for African patients to get access to the treatments, which have multimillion-dollar price tags and are highly complex to manufacture and deliver.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nasra Gwoto, 10, and her brother, Ramadhani, 12, traveled with their mother from Tanzania to India to get a bone-marrow transplant for sickle cell disease. The procedure is risky, and their mother wishes they could have received a new gene therapy instead.

item.title: Premier League TV Rights Deal Steps Back From Streaming
item.description: Why did soccer’s richest league step back from streaming? Maybe because the status quo still pays.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Athletes From Russia and Belarus Are Cleared to Compete at Paris Olympics
item.description: A decision by the International Olympic Committee paves the way for individuals from the two countries to take part over the objections of Ukraine and others.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian athletes at the Beijing Olympics in 2022. While its athletes will be permitted to compete in Paris next year, they must do so without their national colors and flag.

item.title: Biden urges more humanitarian aid for Gaza in a call with Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:description: Palestinians in a camp near Rafah near the border with Egypt on Thursday.

item.title: World’s Stinkiest Cheese Hits Supermarket Shelves in Britain
item.description: Rory Stone, a Scottish cheesemaker, claims to have made the world’s stinkiest cheese. Customers can’t get enough.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:description: Highland Fine Cheeses in Scotland bills the Minger as the most putrid-smelling cheese on earth.

item.title: Thomas Mayo on What Comes After Australia Rejected the Voice
item.description: Thomas Mayo was the calm champion of the effort in Australia to give Indigenous people a voice in Parliament. After its failure, will he turn up the volume?
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Adam Ferguson
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Mayo, an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leader, spent more than a year campaigning for an aboriginal voice to be added to the Australian constitution.

item.title: The Year in ‘Sensitive Content’
item.description: In 2023, Instagram served me images of dead and dying children, heightening social media’s contradictions to a horrific new level.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Hess

item.title: ‘On the brink of full-blown collapse’: Fuel and aid are scarce as relief efforts falter in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians in Al-Mawasi, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: White House Disavows U.S. Islamic Group After Leader’s Oct. 7 Remarks
item.description: The director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations said in a speech that he was “was happy to see” Palestinians break out of Gaza on the day Hamas attacked Israel.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Nihad Awad, the national executive director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, in 2021. He said his remarks in a recent speech were being misconstrued.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Israeli allegations about Hamas’s tactics.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Palestinians strike the concrete of a destroyed building while looking for survivors following Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis.

item.title: Biden Tied Ukraine Aid to Border Security, and It Backfired on Him
item.description: President Biden faces difficult choices about how far to go in giving in to conservative demands that he choke off the number of migrants admitted to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: A U.S. Border Patrol boat passing a large group of migrants crossing a razor wire barrier into the United States at Eagle Pass, Texas, in September. Republican lawmakers want the United States to impose policies that would make most migrants ineligible for asylum.

item.title: Israel Says It Detained Hundreds of Terrorism Suspects in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military said that many had surrendered and been transferred to Israel for further questioning.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Explosions in Khan Younis as seen from Rafah on Thursday.

item.title: Israel Says Hamas Fired Rockets From Near Gaza Shelters
item.description: The claim adds to the growing concerns that there is no safe place in the enclave for those who have been displaced since the war began.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Yara Bayoumy, Aric Toler, Lauren Leatherby and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Palestinians evacuating a wounded woman after an explosion on Thursday in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Denmark Bans Quran Burning
item.description: The law came after a series of public Quran burnings in Scandinavia caused uproar in Muslim communities.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Justice Minister Peter Hummelgaard, second from the left, presenting a bill banning Quran burning, in August.

item.title: In Israel, Hanukkah Begins in the Shadow of Two Months of War
item.description: The holiday held a new meaning for many Israelis in the wake of the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks, including relatives of people still held hostage in Gaza and reservists called up to fight against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members and friends of the people held hostage in Gaza at a candle lighting ceremony in Tel Aviv on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Says Hamas Fired Rockets From Near Shelters
item.description: Plus, “Oppenheimer” is coming to Japan.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians who fled Khan Yunis set up camp in Rafah further south near the border with Egypt, on December 7, 2023, amid continuing battles between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas.

item.title: Son of Israeli War Cabinet Member Killed in Action in Gaza
item.description: Gal Meir Eisenkot, 25, was the son of Lt. Gen. Gadi Eisenkot, a former military chief who went into politics and is part of the group directing the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Gadi Eisenkot, a former chief of staff of the Israeli army, near Jerusalem in February. His son Gal was killed in action in Gaza on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. and Mexico Try to Promote Trade While Curbing Flow of Fentanyl
item.description: In her Mexico City visit, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen sought to deepen economic ties while countering drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen had to strike a delicate balance in Mexico, pushing her counterparts there to work harder to confront fentanyl trafficking while trying to deepen economic ties.

item.title: What Kevin McCarthy and Rishi Sunak Have in Common: Unmanageable Parties
item.description: A former speaker of the U.S. House and the British prime minister have struggled to corral the extreme right factions of their parties.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain with Kevin McCarthy, the former House speaker, in Washington in June.

item.title: A City-Size Iceberg Is Moving Out of Antarctic Waters
item.description: Next up, a yearslong ramble through the Southern Ocean and, eventually, a big melt.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Andrew Meijers/British Antarctic Survey, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A23a is a whole lot of ice. And it’s moving.

item.title: Here is what we know about Israel’s evidence that Hamas fired rockets from safe zones.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler and Lauren Leatherby

item.title: Benjamin Zephaniah, Poet of Social Justice Issues, Dies at 65
item.description: He opened the door for future generations of poets of color to use their own voices.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The British writer and poet Benjamin Zephaniah in Cambridgeshire, England, in 2021.

item.title: Particle Physicists Offer a Road Map For the Next Decade
item.description: A “muon shot” aims to study the basic forces of the cosmos. But meager federal budgets could limit its ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Katrina Miller
item.media:description: A tunnel of the Superconducting Super Collider project in 1993, which was abandoned by Congress.

item.title: Greece and Turkey, Long at Odds, Vow to Work Together Peacefully
item.description: The two rivals have been at the brink of military conflict several times in recent decades. An agreement signed by the countries’ leaders on Thursday aims to change that.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece, center, greeted President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Athens on Thursday before the two leaders signed a “declaration of friendship” pact.

item.title: Lawmakers Press Biden Administration for Tougher Curbs on China Tech
item.description: Republican legislators argue that the Biden administration has been ill-equipped and unmotivated in a technology fight with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee said the administration failed to enforce restrictions on sales of advanced technology to China.

item.title: UK Accuses Russia of Yearslong Cyberattacks
item.description: The government said a group linked to Russia’s intelligence service carried out sustained operations to undermine trust in Britain’s political system.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Megan Specia and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Attempts by Russia “to interfere in U.K. politics are completely unacceptable,” said David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, amid the accusations.

item.title: U.S. Marshal Arrested After Unruly Behavior on Flight to London
item.description: The police in London said the 39-year-old “was disruptive and had sexually assaulted other passengers and crew.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The police in London received reports of a disruptive passenger from the staff on a Delta flight from Kennedy Airport.

item.title: Strike That Killed Reuters Journalist Was ‘Apparently Deliberate’ Israeli Attack, Group Says
item.description: Human Rights Watch found that the slain journalist and six colleagues were not near active fighting in southern Lebanon and would have been clearly visible to Israeli forces.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Hwaida Saad
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch on Thursday released findings from their investigations into the deadly strikes by Israel on southern Lebanon on Oct. 13.

item.title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Will Be Released in Japan After Earlier Backlash
item.description: Critics said the film’s cross-promotion with “Barbie” trivialized the U.S. nuclear attacks on Japan during World War II, but the biopic will be released in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: “Oppenheimer” has since grossed nearly $1 billion in box office sales worldwide, but the film has not yet been screened in Japan.

item.title: Russia Sets Date for Presidential Election
item.description: The winner of the contest is widely seen as a foregone conclusion: Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow. The contest in March will be the first presidential election since Mr. Putin ordered the full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

item.title: Ukraine Carries On Fight While Pondering an Erosion of U.S. Aid
item.description: The government in Kyiv remains hopeful of further American assistance, but it is also looking to other resources — and trying to make clear what could be at stake.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Lara Jakes and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing a self-propelled howitzer in the Kharkiv region on Wednesday.

item.title: Climate Change Makes East Africa’s Deadly Floods Worse, Study Finds
item.description: The extreme rain and flooding in Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia this fall has been made twice as intense by climate change, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: A section of road destroyed by floods in Mororo in northeastern Kenya on Nov. 30.

item.title: Girl Kills Schoolmate and Wounds 5 in Russia Shooting
item.description: The authorities said investigators were working to establish the motive for the shooting, which took place in the city of Bryansk, near the border with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: The regional governor of the Bryansk region called the shootings a “terrible tragedy.”

item.title: Key Events in Israel and Gaza Since Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: On Oct. 7, Hamas and other militant groups launched an attack in Israel that killed hundreds. Israel responded with a military campaign that has devastated Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of the music festival a few days after Hamas opened fire on crowds of civilians in Israel on Oct. 7.

item.title: Israel Is Targeting Hamas With Battlefield Intelligence
item.description: Israel has recovered a trove of material that its military has used to assess the extent of the group’s attack plans, and its tactics and abilities, information reviewed by The Times shows.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier near a tank in Gaza City last month in a photograph taken while New York Times journalists were escorted in the enclave by the Israeli military.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Feel the Bite of Polish Truckers’ Protest
item.description: A border blockade by haulers angry that the European Union has suspended a permit system for their Ukrainian counterparts has led to problems with deliveries of wartime supplies.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Trucks stuck near a border crossing between Poland and Ukraine in November. The blockade action is entering its second month and shows no signs of nearing a resolution.

item.title: Hundreds of thousands are sheltering in Al-Mawasi and the surrounding region, aid workers say.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Liam Stack and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle near the Israel-Gaza border on Thursday.
